title: 109_hr5892
content: The "Farmers Tax Deferral Act" allows for the nontaxable exchange of qualified agricultural property for real property under section 1046 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. No gain or loss recognized for qualified person receiving US real property in exchange for qualified agricultural property. Qualified person defined as individual age 55+, corporation owned by individuals 55+, or partnership/trust/estate with all beneficial interests owned by individuals 55+. Qualified Agricultural Property includes single purpose agricultural structures placed in service by the taxpayer over 20 years before transfer in the exchange described. The section defines qualified agricultural property as single purpose agricultural structures placed in service by the taxpayer over 20 years before the transfer in the exchange. United States real property refers to real property located in the United States. The property must be identified and the exchange completed within 180 days after the transfer of exchanged property. The term 'United States real property' refers to real property located in the United States. Any property received by the taxpayer must be identified within 45 days and the exchange completed within 180 days after the transfer of exchanged property. The taxpayer must receive the property within 45 days after transferring the relinquished property, or within 180 days after the transfer, or by the due date of the tax return for the year of the transfer. The taxpayer must receive the property within specific timeframes after transferring the relinquished property, determined by the due date of the tax return for the year of the transfer. Rules similar to section 1031 apply for basis, exchanges not solely in kind, and related parties. Transactions described in this section are treated similarly to section 1031 exchanges for tax purposes. The section states that transactions described in it will be treated like section 1031 exchanges for tax purposes. Additionally, a special rule is added for like-kind exchanges of qualified agricultural property. Special rule for like-kind exchanges of qualified agricultural property under section 1046(c) limits the amount of gain taken into account by the transferor. The transferor's gain on disposition shall not exceed the sum of the recognized gain and the fair market value of property acquired, excluding certain types of property. The lesser of the excess of the amount realized on the disposition of real property acquired in an exchange or ordinary income recapture on disposition of such property. The disposition of real property under section 1046 involves calculating the lesser of the excess of the amount realized over the adjusted basis, or the excess of the fair market value over the adjusted basis. The disposition of qualified agricultural property involves calculating the excess of the fair market value over the adjusted basis or the amount of gain treated as ordinary income if sold at fair market value. The excess of fair market value over the adjusted basis of qualified agricultural property sold at fair market value is treated as ordinary income. The amendments made by this Act treat gain from the disposition of qualified agricultural property as ordinary income, regardless of other provisions in the tax code. The effective date for these amendments is after the enactment of the Act. Special rules apply to installment sales of qualified agricultural property under Section 3. Special rule for qualified agricultural property under Section 453 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for income from installment sales to be treated differently. The special rule under Section 453 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows income from installment sales to be taken into account under the installment method, with income recognized in proportion as recapture income. The special rule under Section 453 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows income from installment sales to be taken into account under the installment method, with income recognized in proportion as recapture income. A conforming amendment is made to paragraph (3) of section 453(i) of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to sales after the enactment of this Act.
